intro: Epithelantha greggii, commonly known as the Gregg's ghost flower, is a species of flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Cactaceae family and is characterized by its short, cylindrical stems and clusters of small, white, star-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky, well-drained soils and is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments. Epithelantha greggii is known for its ephemeral blooming cycle, often flowering after rainfall in late spring or early summer. Its unique appearance and ecological significance make it a notable species in desert ecosystems.
